title: R44186
content: This report discusses appropriations for the components of the Department of Homeland Security included in the homeland security appropriations bill for FY2016. It covers the Office of the Secretary, Executive Management, Under Secretary for Management, DHS headquarters consolidation project, Chief Financial Officer, Chief Information Officer, Analysis and Operations, and Inspector General. Congress has labeled these components as "Departmental Management and Operations." The report compares the Administration's FY2016 request with the appropriations proposed by Congress and enacted so far. The report on homeland security appropriations for FY2016 includes information on provisions throughout the proposed bills that directly affect DHS functions. It tracks legislative action and congressional issues related to discretionary funding amounts, but does not analyze mandatory funding or other legislation related to DHS programs. The discussion involves specialized budgetary concepts explained in the appendix of CRS Report R44053. The curr_chunk discusses terms related to appropriations process, budget authority, and calculations for homeland security appropriations. It references CRS Report R42388 and the Government Accountability Office's glossary for further information. Amounts in CRS reports are rounded to the nearest million, but unrounded data is used for precision in percentages and totals. Data for FY2015 amounts are derived from the Department of Homeland Security Appropriations Act, 2015 (P.L. 114-4). The curr_chunk provides information on the sources of data used for analyzing DHS appropriations, including the FY2016 budget request, recommended funding levels from Senate and House reports, and enacted appropriations. It references various legislative documents such as P.L. 114-113 and S.Rept. 114-68. The Homeland Security Appropriations Act, 2016 (P.L. 114-113) allocates annual funding for DHS operations, with discretionary appropriations making up the majority of the budget. The bill is organized into five thematic titles covering different departmental components. The Homeland Security Appropriations Act, 2016 allocates annual funding for DHS operations through five thematic titles. Title I provides funding for department management activities, Analysis and Operations account, and the Office of the Inspector General. Departmental Management and Operations components make up about 3% of the discretionary appropriations requested for DHS for FY2016. The Homeland Security Appropriations Act, 2016 allocated $1,546 million for Title I components in FY2016, an increase of $405 million (35.5%) from FY2015 and $150 million (10.7%) more than the requested amount. The enacted funding levels for Departmental Management and Operations components for FY2015 and FY2016 are compared, including amounts requested by the Administration, recommended by Senate and House appropriations committees, and provided by the enacted annual appropriation for FY2016. The departmental management accounts cover general administrative expenses of DHS, including the Office of the Secretary and Executive Management, Under Secretary for Management, and its components. The Administration requested $702 million for departmental management, including funding for various offices such as OCHCO, OCPO, OCSO, OCFO, and OCIO. This total also included $43 million for a financial systems consolidation effort. The requested amounts for OSEM, USM, and OCFO showed increases above the FY2015 levels. The Administration requested $321 million for OCIO, an increase of $32 million (11.3%) from FY2015. S. 1619 included $675 million for departmental management and $36 million for financial systems consolidation. H.R. 3128 included $690 million for departmental management and $53 million for financial systems consolidation. Total funding provided was $701 million. The law provided total funding of $701 million for Departmental Management in Title I, including $203 million in general provisions. This was a decrease of $2 million from the President's request, but an increase of $160 million in funding provided through general provisions. The Administration requested $134 million for OSEM, with H.R. 3128 including $132 million and S. 1619 including $133 million. Title I of P.L. 114-113 provided $137 million for OSEM. The House committee recommended the requested $5 million for the Joint Requirements Council (JRC) and specified requirements for the submission of reports on visa overstay data. The House committee recommended $5 million for the Joint Requirements Council (JRC) and directed the department to provide updates on JRC efforts to reform joint operations within DHS. Quarterly briefings on improving joint requirements were also mandated. Expectations were set for tracking unmanned aircraft systems usage and submitting reports on feasibility, cost, and compliance with privacy laws. The House committee directed the department to submit reports on implementing a universal complaint system and addressing low employee morale. They also requested a briefing on countering violent extremism programs within 60 days. The House committee directed the department to allocate $50 million for emergent threats from violent extremism and complex coordinated terrorist attacks. The funds will be used for a CVE initiative, assisting states and local communities, and expanding the Joint Counterterrorism Awareness Workshop Series. The House committee directed the allocation of $50 million for emergent threats from violent extremism and complex coordinated terrorist attacks. Funding will be provided on a competitive basis to various entities, with specific directives for the Office of Partnership and Engagement and the Office of Policy to report on their initiatives within specified timeframes. The House committee directed the Office of Policy to ensure full participation in interagency discussions on visa policy matters and coordinate with components to finalize metrics for improved border security. The Office of Immigration Statistics was directed to develop a plan for collecting and reporting data on immigration enforcement activities. The House committee directed the Office of Policy to ensure full participation in interagency discussions on visa policy matters and coordinate with components to finalize metrics for improved border security. The Office of Immigration Statistics was directed to develop a plan for collecting and reporting complete and accurate data on immigration enforcement activities, including data from the Executive Office for Immigration Review and the Office of Refugee Resettlement. The plan should result in outcome-based metrics on immigration enforcement that are consistent and can be released to the public regularly. Both the House and Senate reports addressed increased wildlife trafficking, with the House report directing the Secretary to report on the department's activities to address wildlife trafficking within 120 days of the act's enactment. The department is focusing on addressing wildlife trafficking and illegal natural resources trade, including rhinoceros horns and elephant ivory from Africa, and illegally harvested timber. Efforts include membership on the Presidential Task Force on Wildlife Trafficking, improving coordination with the USFWS Office of Law Enforcement, implementing the National Strategy on Wildlife Trafficking, and aligning resources to combat these issues. The Senate report emphasizes the need for improved cooperation and coordination among agencies to address wildlife trafficking. The Secretary is directed to update the report on these activities within 120 days of the act's enactment. The Administration requested $193 million for the USM and 822 FTEs. S. 1619 included $184 million for the USM, $9 million less than requested. H.R. 3128 included $194 million for the USM, less than $1 million more than requested. Title I of Division F of P.L. 114-113 provided $197 million for the USM, $3.6 million more than requested. The Human Resources Information Technology program received almost $8 million. The Under Secretary is required to include a Comprehensive Acquisition Status Report in the FY2017 budget proposal and thereafter, within 45 days after each quarter. The CASR will be posted on the department's public website with all programs displayed by appropriation and PPA, and briefings on acquisition projects at levels 1, 2, and 3 are required. The House report expressed concern over DHS components' inability to communicate effectively and directed the USM to provide a plan for interoperable communications within 90 days. The USM was directed to develop guidance for managing IT enterprise architecture within 90 days of the act's enactment. The plan must focus on a consumption-based IT business model and address operational communications shortfalls. Briefings to House and Senate Committees on Appropriations are required to outline how joint communications requirements will be managed for interoperability across components. The USM was directed to develop guidance for managing IT enterprise architecture within 90 days of the act's enactment, focusing on a consumption-based IT business model and addressing operational communications shortfalls. Appropriations for the Office of the Chief Security Officer and Office of the Chief Procurement Officer were recommended by Senate and House reports, with increases in funding for Continuous Evaluation and critical personnel. The committee recommended almost $61 million in funding, including an increase of $2 million for critical personnel needed by Program Accountability and Risk Management (PARM) to oversee major acquisition programs. The requested funding to comply with the DATA Act was also recommended, which requires unique identification numbers for procurements. The Office of the Chief Human Capital Officer (OCHCO) requested $34 million, with the Senate report recommending less than $27 million, mainly for salaries and expenses (S&E). The House report recommended $31 million, with a key difference in the treatment of the Administration's CyberSkills initiative. The recommended appropriations for the OCIO and NPPD included funding for the CyberSkills initiative, while the House report indicated it was not funded. The Senate-reported bill allocated less than $8 million for Human Resources Information Technology, $2 million less than the budget request and House-reported bill. The explanatory statement recommended $32 million, with $24 million for S&E. $2.5 million funded the CyberSkills initiative, $2.5 million for management of hiring processes, and up to $350,000 for the DHS Leader Development Program. The Senate and House bills included $30 million for the Office of the Chief Readiness Support Officer, with $27 million for salaries and expenses and almost $3 million for repairs to the Nebraska Avenue Complex. The House report directed the office to provide quarterly updates on the common flying hour program and expand the Field Efficiencies Pilot Program to 10 additional cities by the end of FY2016. The explanatory statement recommended almost $32 million, with $27 million for S&E and over $4 million for repairs to the Nebraska Avenue Complex. The Administration requested $97 million for the OCFO and 228 FTEs, with $54 million allocated for the OCFO in Title I and an additional $43 million for financial systems modernization efforts in Title V. The FY2016 request represented a $11 million increase from FY2015. The Senate Appropriations Committee recommended $89 million for the OCFO, $8 million less than requested, citing program delays. H.R. 3128 included $109 million for the Financial Systems Modernization Program, $12 million above the request. P.L. 114-113 provided almost $13 million more than requested for OCFO investments. The Senate Appropriations Committee recommended $3 million for improving financial management processes and cost estimation capabilities. Title V funding will allow the Secretary to allocate resources according to the program execution plan for modernization. Both House- and Senate-reported bills require the Secretary to submit the Future Years Homeland Security Program (FYHSP) alongside the President's budget. Division F of P.L. 114-113 continues to require budget and staffing reports to be submitted to the House and Senate Appropriations Committees within 30 days after each month. The House Appropriations Committee report directed the OCFO to develop a regulation on financial management to establish policies, ensure compliance with accounting standards, enforce internal control policies, ensure accurate disbursement information, and provide oversight of financial activities. Recommended funding is $3 million. The House committee report recommended $3 million in funding for subject matter experts and support staff to assist with developing regulations and implementing a common appropriations structure for the department. They also directed the GAO to assess the risks of utilizing the Department of Interior's Business Center (IBC) for financial management services and compare it to other shared service providers. The OCFO was instructed to update the estimate of lifecycle costs for migrating to a Federal shared service provider. The explanatory statement criticized the department's budget justification materials as inadequate, directing the inclusion of tables comparing prior year actuals, current year estimates, and projected year appropriations. The Administration requested $321 million for the OCIO and 382 FTEs, with S. 1619 and H.R. 3128 providing slightly less funding. Both bills allocated almost $105 million within the total appropriation. The House and Senate Appropriations Committees recommended funding levels for OCIO salaries and expenses, information technology services, infrastructure, and security activities. Title I of Division F of P.L. 114-113 provided $310 million for OCIO, slightly less than requested. Within the OCIO account, salaries and expenses received $110 million, while development and acquisition of IT equipment and services received $200 million. The funds were directed to support initiatives such as the DHS Data Framework and security measures. The Federal Risk and Authorization Management Program, Trusted Tester Program, and Infrastructure Transformation Program received funding for cybersecurity in addition to base funding for the CIO and components. The $100 million is intended to enhance DHS network security, access controls, authentication, equipment upgrades, data loss prevention, and incident response. The CIO is directed to lead in protecting data and systems. The CIO was directed to utilize a risk-based approach for cybersecurity investments and operations, brief committees on spending and metrics, and support the Cyberskills Support Initiative. The OCIO was tasked with providing semi-annual briefings on major initiatives. The OCIO was directed to provide semi-annual briefings on major initiatives and investment areas. The Senate report emphasized the need for the Digital Services Team to address challenges in immigration data reporting as a top priority by December 2015. The House Appropriations Committee did not recommend funding for this program, but the explanatory statement suggested using up to $10 million of the S&E funds for Digital Services. The Senate Appropriations Committee also expected DHS to support NASA in data center consolidation efforts and continue briefings on data center migration funds. The House report directed the OCIO to provide briefings on data center migration funds, future plans, and open market strategy for cloud services. They also requested updates on enterprise architecture, savings from data center consolidation, and preventing data loss at the enterprise level. Funding levels for existing management functions were outlined in Table 2. The House and Senate Appropriations Committees discussed issues related to departmental management and administration in the FY2016 Department of Homeland Security Appropriations bill. These issues included acquisition matters and the implementation of a common appropriations structure, which were related to the department's Unity of Effort initiative. The Senate Appropriations Committee directed DHS to provide a briefing on procurement process metrics within 120 days, while the House Appropriations Committee noted the USM's role as the Department's Chief. The House Appropriations Committee report directed the USM to develop written guidance by April 1, 2016, to clarify roles and responsibilities for overseeing program management of major IT acquisition programs, provide cost estimates for operations and maintenance, track adherence to cost estimates, and enter data into the next generation Period Reporting System on a quarterly basis. The House Appropriations Committee directed the Executive Director of PARM to provide quarterly briefings on major acquisition programs by component starting April 15, 2016. Both Senate and House Appropriations Committees discussed potential reform of the DHS budget structure. The House Appropriations Committee highlighted the need to strengthen DHS budget processes to address significant disparities and inconsistencies in appropriations accounts. The lack of transparency and uniformity in budgeting makes it difficult to compare costs and track fund utilization. The DHS presented a common appropriations structure with four standard types of appropriations and specific periods of availability. The Senate Appropriations Committee emphasized the importance of transparency in tracking funds from planning to execution for departmental oversight and resource allocation. The House Appropriations Committee supports the common appropriations structure proposed by DHS, stating it enables cost comparisons and simplifies the transition to modernized systems. They mandated the implementation of this structure in the fiscal year 2017 budget request and directed DHS to develop a standard template for budget justifications based on this structure for the FY2018 budget request. The House Appropriations Committee mandated the implementation of a common appropriations structure proposed by DHS in the FY2017 budget request. They directed DHS to develop a standard template for budget justifications based on this structure for the FY2018 budget request, starting from a zero base and including comparison tables for appropriations and obligations. The new general provision authorized the Secretary to include an account structure in the budget justification. The general provision establishes a timeline, procedures, and requirements for the Secretary to transfer and reprogram funds into the new structure, including materials to be submitted by the CFO by April 1, 2016. This includes technical assistance on new legislative language, tables comparing funding across fiscal years, comparisons across components, a revised financial management policy manual, proposed changes to requirements for transfers and reprogramming, and CFO certification. The Department of Homeland Security is working to consolidate its headquarters, currently spread across 50 locations in the Washington, DC area. This fragmentation leads to inefficiencies and increased costs. Efforts are being made to unify headquarters functions and reduce these issues. The Department of Homeland Security and General Services Administration approved a $3.4 billion plan to create a new DHS headquarters at St. Elizabeths in Anacostia, the largest federal office construction since the Pentagon. Phase 1A, a new Coast Guard headquarters, has been completed. Funding requests have been made for consolidation of other offices to save on lease costs. DHS and GSA requested $204 million and $380 million for the FY2016 funding of a revised plan for DHS headquarters consolidation at St. Elizabeths. The new plan reduces cost and size, providing 3.6 billion square feet of office space at $3.7 billion. It will house 3,000 additional personnel, totaling 17,000. The requested funding for DHS headquarters consolidation at St. Elizabeths would support perimeter security, road access improvements, building rehabilitation, and construction to accommodate 40% more personnel. The total request for headquarters consolidation is almost $216 million, with $212 million allocated in Senate-reported S. 1619. The Senate committee report includes funding for DHS headquarters consolidation at St. Elizabeths, with a requirement for an expenditure plan and quarterly briefings. The project aims to consolidate 32,000 employees from 50 locations into a more affordable enhanced plan. The Department now has a more affordable enhanced plan for the St. Elizabeths project, with cost savings and avoidance. The House-reported H.R. 3128 includes funding for DHS headquarters consolidation, with significant savings over 30 years compared to relying on multiple rented facilities. The recommendation provides funding for the DHS headquarters consolidation at the consolidated headquarters location, with almost $216 million allocated for the project, including over $3 million for security services. The department must submit an expenditure plan within 90 days of the act's enactment. The total funding provided in FY2016 for this project is $557 million, representing the largest tranche of funding for DHS headquarters consolidation. The project receives the largest funding for DHS headquarters consolidation since 2009, including resources for the Office of Intelligence and Analysis and the Office of Operations Coordination. I&A manages the DHS intelligence enterprise and shares intelligence information with various partners. The Office of Operations Coordination develops and coordinates departmental and interagency operations plans, including managing the National Operations Center. The National Operations Center is the main hub for domestic incident management and operations coordination, combining law enforcement, intelligence, emergency response, and private sector information. The Administration requested $269 million for the Analysis and Operations account, with the Senate recommending $263 million. The committee required a briefing on the expenditure plan within 60 days of enactment. DHS was also directed to continue briefings on state and local fusion centers, with a focus on establishing a state-level "center of excellence" for threats assessment. The feasibility of establishing a state-level "center of excellence" focusing on cybersecurity and critical infrastructure threats in the United States is being considered. The center aims to enhance partnerships for threat information sharing among federal, state, and private sector entities. House-reported H.R. 3128 recommended $265 million for Analysis and Operations, slightly below the Administration's request. Additionally, $300,000 was allocated for enhancing the Criminal Intelligence Enterprise to identify and prioritize threat groups. The DHS Office of the Inspector General (OIG) is an independent body that audits and investigates department activities to prevent waste, fraud, and abuse. It is required to report to Congress and the Secretary of DHS. The Administration requested $142 million for the OIG, $24 million more than the previous appropriation. The DHS OIG received a $142 million appropriation, with an additional $24 million requested for oversight of disaster relief activities. The OIG's initial budget request was larger than what was ultimately approved, with reductions made during the budget formulation process. The DHS OIG requested additional funding for high-risk areas in DHS, citing historical underfunding. The Senate-reported bill allocated $134 million, slightly below the request, while the House-reported bill allocated $141 million, slightly below the request. Both bills included a transfer from the DRF for disaster relief oversight activities. The omnibus bill included a $137 million appropriation for the DHS OIG, slightly below the requested amount but higher than the previous year. Issues surrounding the DHS OIG impact the broader oversight community and are discussed in detail in CRS reports.
